signalslink:block-handbooktext-blocksens:
The Block Sensor detects the presence of a block at a selected adjacent position and, based on its type (and optionally an input signal), provides output information about its state or slot fill level.
Currently supported blocks are:
Anvil - if there is a sufficiently hot ingot on the anvil for forging, the Output signal is 1. Otherwise it outputs signal 0.
Doors, gates, trapdoors - For doors and gates you need to monitor the ground-level block on the hinge side. If the block is open, the Output signal is 1; if it is closed, the Output signal is 0.
Chest or generally a container or any blocks that have inventory slots (e.g. firepit, barrel, trough, etc.). The Output signal depends on the input signal.
The input signal determines which slot is to be scanned.
Signal 1-14 selects slots 0-13. The output is information about how full the slot is relative to the maximum stack capacity of the item in that slot, converted to a 0-15 signal.
Signal 15 indicates that the sensor should detect the overall fill level of all slots, e.g. the entire chest.
Some other block not listed above - If there is nothing in the monitored space (air), the Output signal is 0. If there is water, the output is 2 for fresh water or 3 for salt water. If there is any other block, the Output signal is 1.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-entitysen:
The Entity Sensor detects the presence of entities (players, animals, wild animals, or monsters) in the marked area and can provide information on its outputs about their count, type, or state. The sensor requires one or more Temporal gears to be charged to operate. The consumption rate depends on the size of the monitored area.
Inputs x, y, z determine the size of the monitored area in blocks.
On the Error output there is signal 1 if the sensor is discharged, otherwise 0.
Inputs Output 1 setting and Output 2 setting determine what information will be provided on outputs 1 and 2. You can thus get different information on each output based on these input settings.
Options are:
1 - Output returns Count. The number of detected entities.
2 - Output returns Category. Bit flags for entity categories 0–3: player, creature, animal, wild animal.
3 - Output returns Life state. All detected entities are: 1–dead, 2–alive, or 15–mixed.
4 - Output returns Sex. All detected entities are: 1–male, 2–female, or 15–mixed.
5 - Output returns Age. All detected entities are: 1–young, 2–adult, or 15–mixed.
6 - Output returns Species. All detected entities are: 1–player, 2–animal, 3–wild animal, 4–creature, or 15–mixed.
7 - Output returns Reproductive state. All detected entities are: 1–ready to mate, 2–pregnant, 3–lactating, or 15–mixed.
8 - Output returns Reproductive state flags. Bit flags 0–2: ready to mate, pregnant, lactating.
9 - Output returns Minimum generation. The minimum detected generation is: 0–15. Entities without a specified generation are ignored.
10 - Output returns Maximum generation. The maximum detected generation is: 0–15. Entities without a specified generation are ignored.
11 - Output returns Minimum weight. The minimum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
12 - Output returns Maximum weight. The maximum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedch:
The Managed Chute enables automated transport of items between different blocks. It moves items only in one direction, which is indicated on the chute by a white arrow.
Unlike a chute, the managed chute does not have its own inventory and transports items from the block on the source side directly into the block on the target side. This means items are not stored in the chute, but are only passed through it.
The managed chute has three Signals connectors: Input, Source, and Target.
Input is used to control transport. If there is a signal 0 on the Input, the chute is inactive and does not transport any items. A non-zero value on the input triggers transport of items from the source to the target. The following input values are supported:
1 - Transport 1 item
2 - Transport 2 items
3 - Transport 4 items
4 - Transport 8 items
5 - Transport 16 items
6 - Transport 32 items
7 - Transport 64 items
15 - Transport continuously.
Input values 1-7 allow transporting items in batches. If there are not enough items in the source block to transport the requested amount, the chute will transport as many as it can and deliver the rest when another input appears. If you want to transport a different quantity, you can successively send different signal values in the range 1 to 7 to the input and thus compose the desired batch size.
Value 15 on the input causes the chute to transport items from the source to the target continuously, regardless of how many items need to be transported. The chute will continue transporting items as soon as they appear in the source until the input signal is changed to another value.
Transport occurs if there is something available to transport on the source side and at the same time there is space on the target side to store the items. If either of these conditions is not met, the chute will attempt to transport items, but if it is not possible, it will remain inactive until the situation changes (e.g., items appear in the source or space is freed in the target).
Source is relevant if the input block is a block with an inventory. In that case, the signal on Source determines from which slot items should be taken. Signal 1-14 specifies slots 0-13. Signal 15 means items should be taken from the last slot.
Signal 0 means items should be taken from any slot. In this case, the chute searches all slots and takes items from the first slot that is not empty. If the source block has no inventory, this input is ignored.
Target is relevant if the output block is a block with an inventory or air. For an inventory, the signal on Target determines into which slot items should be stored. Signal 1-15 specifies slots 0-14.
If the target block is air and there is ground beneath it, these target values are relevant: 1 - the chute will try to place a block from the source onto the ground, 2 - the chute will try to place an item onto the ground if it is placeable. This currently works only with coal and is useful e.g. for automatic stoking under a steelmaking furnace.

If the source block is air, the chute will collect floating items from a 3x3 block area, where the middle block of this cube is the block in front of the chute mouth.

In addition to the above, the managed chute can also insert ingots, Iron Bloom, and Blister Steel into an anvil if the anvil is placed on the target side of the chute. When inserting ingots onto an anvil, the plate forging recipe is selected automatically. For Iron Bloom and Blister Steel, slag removal is selected so they become ingots. This is very useful for automating forging with an automatic hammer. Before inserting onto the anvil, however, you must ensure the ingot, Iron Bloom, or Blister Steel is heated to the required temperature.

Transport filtering
The managed chute allows you to set conditions for filtering which items should be transported. Conditions are set using Conditions on Paper, whose usage is explained on this page
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedwa:
A managed chute embedded in a wall enables automated transport of items between different blocks. It allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food preservation.
It works on the same principle as the Managed Chute. You can therefore find the usage description on the page describing the Managed Chute.
signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-text:
SignalsLink
Extends the Signals mod with additional components.

To monitor a nearby block you can use the Block Sensor.
If you need to monitor your herd of livestock, the Entity Sensor is great for that.
If you want to automate some tasks, the Managed Chute will serve you well; it can transport items between blocks similarly to a chute, but you control it with signals and it gives you much greater control over what is transported. Its variant Managed Chute built into a wall then allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food preservation.
signalslink:usageinfo-paperconditions-te:
Some blocks from the SignalsLink mod allow using conditions on paper:
• Block Sensor
• Managed Chute
• Managed Chute embedded in a wall
Conditions on paper
conditions on paper are conditions written on parchment. These conditions can be used to influence a block's behavior, for example to control output signals or to filter items in chutes.
Conditions are written into blocks (paragraphs). Each block consists of one or more lines, where each line contains one condition. All conditions within one block are evaluated by applying the logical AND operator between them, and the result yields the resulting value of the whole block.
Individual blocks are separated by an empty line. The logical OR operator is then applied to the resulting values of the individual blocks. Evaluation of individual conditions in a block proceeds from top to bottom in the order they are written on the paper. Evaluation of blocks also proceeds in the order in which the blocks are written on the paper. This means that as soon as a block evaluates to true, this result is returned to the calling block and subsequent blocks are not processed. This is very important and must be taken into account.

We distinguish several types of conditions:
game:plank-oak - Evaluates whether the observed item in an inventory or the observed block is of the specified type, i.e., its code matches exactly the specified code. If yes, the condition returns true.
game:plank-* - Evaluates whether the observed item or block is of the specified type in any of its variants (marked with an asterisk). If yes, the condition returns true.
@.*-plank-.* - The code of the observed item or block is evaluated using this regular expression. If it matches, the condition returns true.
attribute > 1 - Evaluates the value of an item attribute in an inventory or of an observed block. Various comparison operators can be used here (greater/less/equal). After evaluation, the comparison result is returned (true/false).
attribute - If only the name of an item attribute is provided in the condition, it evaluates whether it has a value or not. That is, zero, NULL, an empty string, or false evaluates as false. A non-zero value, a string, or true evaluates as true.

The negation operator ! can be applied to all conditions. For example, !game:plank-oak evaluates as true if the observed item or block is not exactly oak planks.
At the end of each block, you can add an instruction to set the output signal, for example output 1, which specifies that if this block evaluates to true, signal 1 will be sent to the output. This is only meaningful for the Block Sensor block, which allows setting what signal will be sent to the output if a block or item matches the conditions listed in the block. For other blocks that allow using conditions on paper, this instruction is ignored.Setting conditions
Write the conditions on parchment. Do not sign the parchment so you can edit the text again.
Transfer the conditions into a block that supports it by right-clicking the given block with this parchment. The conditions will be saved into the block and you will see them in the information window when you look at the block.
To remove conditions from a block, take an empty parchment in your hand, crouch (shift key), and right-click the given block with this empty parchment. This deletes the conditions from the block.
If you want to copy conditions from a block onto an empty parchment, right-click the given block with an empty parchment without crouching.
And finally, a tip for finding out what code a block or item has and what attributes are available for use in conditional expressions:
Take the item you are interested in in your hand, hold the ctrl key, and right-click with this block on a block that supports conditions on paper. The item code and its attributes, available for conditions on paper, will be saved into that block. You can now copy them onto an empty parchment as described above, and there freely edit them into condition blocks and use them to configure the block.
